src.data module

@author: Chun Hei Michael Chan @copyright: Private Copyright @credits: [Chun Hei Michael Chan] @maintainer: Chun Hei Michael Chan @email: miki998chan@gmail.com

src.data.combine_timecourse_subcortical(path2mri400, path2labelsub)

Information:

Merge the different fmri timecourse data and arrange them combining 400 regions with subcortical 14 regions

WARNING: very specific function to my usage (filenames are hard-coded)

param path2mri400::[String]:

path to fmri compiled version generated by function “format_timecourse_cortical”

param path2labelsub::[String]:

path to file for subcortical index labels

rtype:

mri_df::[pandas Dataframe]

src.data.df_to_timeseries(df, filename)

Information:

Read our formatted dataframes to obtain timeseries in (time,voxels) format of a specific acquisition

param df ::[DataFrame]:

DataFrame containing mri info

param filename::[string]:

Name of the acquisition we want to single out

returns:

  • series ::[2darray<float>] – timeseries that we are interested in

  • cur_file::[DatFrame] – DataFrame of info about the filename we gave as input

src.data.format_bids(path2data='./data/emoFiles/EmoBIDS/')

Information:

Merge the different emotion data in BIDS csv format and arrange them WARNING: very specific function to my usage (filenames are hard-coded)

param path2data::[String]:

rtype:

emo_df::[pandas Dataframe]

src.data.format_timecourse_cortical(path2mrifolder, path2label)

Information:

Merge the different fmri timecourse data and arrange them including only cortical 400 regions WARNING: very specific function to my usage (filenames are hard-coded)

param path2mrifolder::[String]:

path to fmri timecourse

param path2label ::[String]:

path to file for 7 yeo network index labels

returns:

  • list_mri_df::[list<pandas Dataframe>]

  • names ::[list<String>]

src.gradient_metrics module

@author: Chun Hei Michael Chan @copyright: Private Copyright @credits: [Chun Hei Michael Chan] @maintainer: Chun Hei Michael Chan @email: miki998chan@gmail.com

src.gradient_metrics.cluster_distance(clst1, clst2, method='closest', pmethod='L1')

Information:

Compute distance between two clusters

param clst1 ::[2darray<float>]:

Array of points, point would be of length the number of features (nb_points, nb_features)

param clst2 ::[2darray<float>]:

param method ::[string]:

The type of distance to implement for two clusters

param pmethod::[string]:

The type of distance to implement for two points

returns:

Distance between the two clusters

rtype:

dist::[float]

src.gradient_metrics.gradients_distance(g1, g2, pmethod='L1')

Information:

Compute distance between two clusters

param g1 ::[2darray<float>]:

gradient of a given FC matrix (dimension (nb_region, nb_features))

param g2 ::[2darray<float>]:

gradient of a given FC matrix (dimension (nb_region, nb_features))

param pmethod::[string]:

The type of distance to implement for two points

returns:

Distance between the two gradients (also a distance used for procrustes value)

rtype:

dist::[float]

src.gradient_metrics.gradients_distance2(G1, G2, similarity=False, pmethod='L2')

Information:

Compute the distance between to networks (potentially from same gradients or different gradients)

param G1 ::[2darray<float>]:

First set of Gradients with dimension (nb regions, nb features) that we take network1 from

param G2 ::[2darray<float>]:

Second set of Gradients with dimension (nb regions, nb features) that we take network2 from

param similarity::[Bool]:

similarity metric between two gradients’ extracted features from

param pmethod ::[string]:

The type of distance between points

rtype:

dist::[float]

src.gradient_metrics.mean_region_motion(grads, pmethod='L2')

Information:

Compute average movement of each parcel (400) from dynamic gradients

param grads ::[list<2darray<float>>]:

Gradients with dimension (nb regions, nb features)

param pmethod ::[string]:

The type of distance to implement for two points

returns:

array of parcels’ average movements

rtype:

region_motion::[1darray<float>]

src.gradient_metrics.network_position(grad, network, grad_idx=0)

Information:

Remove mean and normalize by standard deviation on any array size

param grad ::[2darray<float>]:

Gradients with dimension (nb regions, nb features)

param network ::[str]:

Network name: that points to indices in the 400 parcellations that belong to a certain network (e.g “Vis”)

param grad_idx ::[int]:

Which gradient we are estimating the variance of

rtype:

dist::[float]

Information:

Remove mean and normalize by standard deviation on any array size

param grad ::[2darray<float>]:

Gradients with dimension (nb regions, nb features)

param network ::[str]:

Network name: that points to indices in the 400 parcellations that belong to a certain network (e.g “Vis”)

dist::[float]

src.gradient_metrics.network_volume(grad, network, method='distance', pmethod='L2')

Information:

Compute the dispersion / volume generated by the parcels belonging to the same network

param grad ::[2darray<float>]:

Gradients with dimension (nb regions, nb features)

param network ::[str]:

Network name: that points to indices in the 400 parcellations that belong to a certain network (e.g “Vis”)

param method ::[string]:

The type of distance to implement for volume computation

param pmethod ::[string]:

The type of distance to implement for two points

rtype:

dist::[float]

src.gradient_metrics.networks_distance(G1, G2, N1, N2, method='centroid')

Information:

Compute the distance between to networks (potentially from same gradients or different gradients)

param G1 ::[2darray<float>]:

First set of Gradients with dimension (nb regions, nb features) that we take network1 from

param G2 ::[2darray<float>]:

Second set of Gradients with dimension (nb regions, nb features) that we take network2 from

param N1 ::[str]:

Network name: that points to indices in the 400 parcellations that belong to a certain network (e.g “Vis”)

param N2 ::[str]:

Network name: that points to indices in the 400 parcellations that belong to a certain network (e.g “Vis”)

param method::[string]:

The type of distance to implement for volume computation

rtype:

dist::[float]

src.gradient_metrics.parcel_to_network(full_grad, type='grad_centroid', pmethod='L2')

Information:

Compute the distance of each parcels to its respective network or to the general gradient

param full_grad ::[2darray<float>]:

Gradients with dimension (nb regions, nb features)

param type ::[str]:

Name of the reference to compute distance to parcels either “grad_centroid” or “net_centroid”

param pmethod ::[string]:

The type of distance to implement for two points

rtype:

dist::[1darray<float>]

Point would be of length the number of features

param pts2 ::[2darray<float>]:

param pmethod::[string]:

The type of distance to implement for two points

returns:

Distance between the two points

dist::[float]

src.gradient_utils module

@author: Chun Hei Michael Chan @copyright: Private Copyright @credits: [Chun Hei Michael Chan] @maintainer: Chun Hei Michael Chan @email: miki998chan@gmail.com

src.gradient_utils.FC(series, verbose=False)

Information:

Compute the static functional connectivity matrix of a timeseries of fMRI

param series::[2darray<float>]:

fMRI timeseries of dimension : (nb timepoints, nb regions)

returns:

FC of interest of dimension : (nb regions, nb regions)

rtype:

fc::[2darray<float>]

src.gradient_utils.correlation_search(arr1, arr2, tolshift, find=0)

Information:

On a large series

param arr1 ::[1darray<float>]:

First signal

param arr2 ::[1darray<float>]:

Second signal

param tolshift::[int]:

Number of timepoints we are allowed to shift

param find ::[bool]:

Returning index of where the arrays have highest correlation

returns:

  • corr ::[float] – Correlation value modulo shift with limited tolerance

  • tup ::[tuple<int, int>] – Indexes for array1 and array2 to start with for the shift with best correlation

  • p-val::[float] – Significance of correlation

src.gradient_utils.jackknife_FC(series)

Information:

Compute the dynamic functional connectivity matrices of a timeseries of fMRI

param series::[2darray<float>]:

fMRI timeseries of dimension : (nb timepoints, nb regions)

returns:

Dynamic FC of interest of dimension : (nb timestamp, nb regions, nb regions)

rtype:

dFC::[3darray<float>]

src.gradient_utils.pearson_correlation(arr1, arr2)

Information:

Direct pearson correlation

param arr1 ::[1darray<float>]:

First signal

param arr2 ::[1darray<float>]:

Second signal

returns:

Correlation value modulo shift with limited tolerance

rtype:

corr ::[float]

src.gradient_utils.procrustes_align(list_gradients, ref=None, score_flag=True, n_iter=100, tol=1e-05)

Information:

Procruste alignment Evaluations

param list_gradients::[list<2darray<float>>]:

List of gradients each gradients have dimension (nb regions, nb features)

param ref ::[2darray<float>]:

Reference gradients used in alignment (nb regions, nb features)

param score_flag ::[bool]:

True if we want to evalute procrustes score as well

param n_iter ::[int]:

Number of iteration for procrustes alignement

returns:

  • aligned_gradients::[list<2darray<float>>] – List of aligned gradients each gradients have dimension (nb regions, nb features)

  • ref ::[2darray<float>] – Reference gradients used in alignment (nb regions, nb features)

  • score ::[float] – Average procrustes alignment score on across all alignments

src.gradient_utils.procrustes_score(ref_gradient, aligned)

Information:

Read our formatted dataframes to obtain timeseries in (time,voxels) format of a specific acquisition

param ref_gradient::[2darray<float>]:

reference gradients with dimension (nb of region, nb of features) in our case most of times number of features would be the number of eigenvectors

param aligned ::[2darray<float>]:

gradients that we aligned to reference with same dimension as reference gradients

returns:

Score for the alignement process in comparison to the original reference

rtype:

error::[float]

src.gradient_utils.sliding_window_FC(series, ws, step=1)

Information:

Compute the dynamic functional connectivity matrices of a timeseries of fMRI

param series::[2darray<float>]:

fMRI timeseries of dimension : (nb timepoints, nb regions)

param ws ::[int]:

Window size for sliding window

param step ::[int]:

Step size to go from one window to the next one

returns:

Dynamic FC of interest of dimension : (nb windows, nb regions, nb regions)

rtype:

dFC::[3darray<float>]

src.prediction module

@author: Chun Hei Michael Chan @copyright: Private Copyright @credits: [Chun Hei Michael Chan] @maintainer: Chun Hei Michael Chan @email: miki998chan@gmail.com

src.prediction.combination_predict(classifier, hparam_range, X, y, kfold, metric='corr', rd_state=10)

Information:

Find best parameter a specific pair of the issue is we have a overfitting problem, the solutions are not necessarily found, and so we consider a solution to have a postiive R2 values on validaiton

param classifier ::[sklearn.predictor]:

Model used for regression

param hparam_range::[1darray<float>]:

Alpha values for weighting in L1 loss

param X ::[2darray<float>]:

param y ::[1darray<float>]:

param kfold ::[int]:

test fold size

param metric ::[String]:

param rd_state ::[int]:

returns:

all folds’ set of results

rtype:

fold_results::[list<res,coef,pred,valY,corr>]

src.prediction.predict_result(classifier, trainX, trainY, valX, valY, alpha, metric='corr', ret_pred=False)

Information:

Do a train, prediction and evaluation of inputted set

param classifier::[sklearn.predictor]:

Model used for regression

param trainX ::[2darray<float>]:

gradients train set

param trainY ::[2darray<float>]:

label (i.e personality index) train set

param valX ::[2darray<float>]:

gradients validation set

param valY ::[2darray<float>]:

label (i.e personality index) validation set

param alpha ::[float]:

weighting for lasso

param metric ::[String]:

param ret_pred ::[Bool]:

returns:

  • res ::[float] – scoring of classifier on validation

  • coef ::[1darray<float>]

  • prediction::[1darray<float>] – on validation set

src.prediction.sample_solution(classifier, hparam_range, X, y, kfold, nrepeat, null=False, metric='corr', rd_state=10)

test fold size

param nrepeat ::[int]:

param metric ::[String]:

all folds’ set of results

fold_results::[list<res,coef,corr>]

src.stats_utils module

@author: Chun Hei Michael Chan @copyright: Private Copyright @credits: [Chun Hei Michael Chan] @maintainer: Chun Hei Michael Chan @email: miki998chan@gmail.com

src.stats_utils.moviemix_stat_test(totest, mainseries, mixseries)

Information:

Compute null distribution and main correlation (null distrib is defined as set of correlations obtained from all continuous timecourses of same size as the main one applied on all the other timecourses)

param totest ::[1darray<float>]:

Most of times in our case would be metric series

param mainseries::[1darray<float>]:

Most of times in our case would be emotion series of a interest movie

param mixseries ::[1darray<float>]:

Most of times in our case would be emotion series of all but the interest movie

returns:

  • ndistrib::[1darray<float>]

  • nscore ::[float]

  • cur ::[float] – p-value

src.stats_utils.null_score(null_distrib, sample)

Information:

Give the p-value of estimated value against a null distribution

param null_distrib::[1darray<float>]:

param sample ::[float]:

returns:

p-value

rtype:

score::[float]

src.stats_utils.plot_nulldistribution(totest, mainseries, mixseries)

Information:

Plot the null distribution for shifted series test

param totest ::[1darray<float>]:

Most of times in our case would be metric series

param mainseries::[1darray<float>]:

Most of times in our case would be emotion series of a interest movie

param mixseries ::[1darray<float>]:

Most of times in our case would be emotion series of all but the interest movie

rtype:

None

src.stats_utils.shift_series_nulldistribution(Y, othermoviesdf, emotion_df, smfactor=1)

Information:

(Wrap moviemixstat) Compute null distribution and main correlation (null distrib is defined as set of correlations obtained from all continuous timecourses of same size as the main one applied on all the other timecourses)

param Y ::[1darray<float>]:

Metric series

param othermoviesdf::[DataFrame]:

Dataframe of other movies

param emotion_df ::[DataFrame]:

Dataframe of current movie with which we computed Y. All emotions are considered for the current movie.

returns:

  • ret_score ::[1darray<float>] – correlations for each emotion

  • ret_nscore ::[1darray<float>] – p-value for each emotion

src.utils.compare_videos(arr1, arr2)

Information:

Read our formatted dataframes to obtain timeseries in (time,voxels) format of a specific acquisition

param arr1::[4darray<uint8>]:

First Stream of images (to be concatenated in the left side)

param arr2::[4darray<uint8>]:

Second Stream of images (to be concatenated in the right side)

returns:

Stream of images that were concatenated horizontally together

rtype:

concat::[4darray<uint8>]

src.utils.design_variance(X, which_predictor=1)

Returns the design variance of a predictor (or contrast) in X.

Parameters:

  • X (numpy array) – Array of shape (N, P)

  • which_predictor (int or list/array) – The index of the predictor you want the design var from. Note that 0 refers to the intercept! Alternatively, “which_predictor” can be a contrast-vector (which will be discussed later this lab).

Returns:

des_var – Design variance of the specified predictor/contrast from X.

Return type:

float

src.utils.img2video(img_array, fps, outpath_name='out.mp4')

param fps ::[int]:

Encoding/Displaying fps

param outpath_name::[string]:

Path and name of the video file to output

rtype:

None::[None]

If true then pad the boundaries to return an array of same size as input If false then leave boundaries not computed
